Rare construct with זָרַע - 'seed-bag', 'trail', or 'drawing out' unclear
Root appears in inclusio (vv.1,4) - full semantic range in restoration contexts
Hiphil form with לַעֲשׂוֹת - precise force of 'magnified to do' construction
Appears vv.2,5,6 - semantic range between joy, singing, shouting
Sheaves imagery - agricultural technical term for contrast with seed

commentary_requests.reason: Opening temporal ambiguity - how commentators resolve בְּשׁוּב (past/present/future) and כְּחֹלְמִים dream imagery
Nations as witnesses - traditional interpretation of gentiles recognizing YHWH's greatness
Verbatim repetition puzzle - why Israel echoes nations' words with pronoun shift
Negeb watercourses simile - classical understanding of sudden flooding metaphor and shift to petition
Proverbial wisdom shift - how commentators connect agricultural saying to restoration theology
Intensive verbal forms and מֶשֶׁךְ־הַזָּרַע - traditional exegesis of emphatic constructions and rare phrase

macro_questions: What is the precise temporal reference and function of בְּשׁוּב in v.1—past event, present conditional, prophetic perfect, or deliberate ambiguity—and how do ancient versions (LXX, Targum, Vulgate) interpret this?

How does the phrase כְּחֹלְמִים ('like dreamers'/'like those dreaming') function rhetorically—as positive (restoration so wonderful it seemed unreal) or ambiguous (still only a dream/hope), and what are biblical parallels to dream imagery in contexts of deliverance?
What is the theological significance of the nations' recognition in v.2, and how does this relate to prophetic themes of Israel as YHWH's witness (cf. Isaiah 52:10, Ezekiel 36:23-24)?
What is the rhetorical and theological effect of the shift from 'them' (אֵלֶּה, v.2) to 'us' (עִמָּנוּ, v.3), and does this suggest quotation-then-appropriation structure?

What are the agricultural and meteorological realities of wadis/watercourses (אֲפִיקִים) in the Negeb—how often do they flood, what triggers it, and what transformation occurs—and how does this inform the metaphor?
Are vv.5-6 quoting a known proverbial saying, or is this original composition in proverbial style—are there parallels in wisdom literature or Ancient Near Eastern agricultural proverbs?
How does the agricultural metaphor relate to exilic/post-exilic theology—is there wordplay between זֶרַע (seed) and זֶרַע (offspring/descendants), connecting sowing to national restoration?

What is the precise function and emphasis of the intensive verbal constructions (absolute infinitive) הָלוֹךְ יֵלֵךְ and בֹּא־יָבֹא in v.6—durative action, emphasis, certainty, or narrative vividness?
How does Psalm 126 relate literarily and thematically to other Songs of Ascents, particularly those dealing with restoration (Psalms 122, 125, 129) and agricultural imagery (Psalm 128)?

What is the relationship between מֶשֶׁךְ־הַזָּרַע ('seed-bag' or 'trail of seed') and אֲלֻמֹּתָיו ('his sheaves')—is there quantitative contrast (little seed vs. abundant harvest) or merely qualitative (what is sown vs. what is reaped)?
Does the psalm's structure suggest liturgical performance—could vv.1-3 be sung by one group/voice and vv.4-6 by another, creating a call-and-response pattern in pilgrimage procession?
micro_questions: Why is the temporal reference of בְּשׁוּב in v.1 ambiguous—is this deliberate liturgical strategy allowing multiple generations to inhabit the text, or textual/grammatical issue?
What is the precise meaning and etymology of שִׁיבַת/שְׁבִית in vv.1,4—'captivity,' 'fortunes,' or both—and why does the Ketiv/Qere variation exist?
How does the simile כְּחֹלְמִים ('like dreamers') function—does it suggest restoration seemed unreal (too wonderful), or that they're still only dreaming (unfulfilled hope)?
Why do the nations speak first in v.2, then Israel echoes them in v.3—is this theological claim about Israel learning identity through others' witness, or rhetorical structure?
What are the specific meteorological/agricultural realities of אֲפִיקִים בַּנֶּגֶב (watercourses in Negeb)—how often do they flood, what triggers it, and what transformation occurs?
Is the proverbial saying in vv.5-6 quoting a known wisdom tradition, or creating original proverb in traditional style—are there ANE parallels to sowing-in-tears/reaping-in-joy?
What is מֶשֶׁךְ־הַזָּרַע in v.6—'seed-bag,' 'trail of seed,' 'drawing out seed'—and is there implied quantitative contrast with אֲלֻמֹּתָיו (sheaves)?
Why the intensive verbal constructions הָלוֹךְ יֵלֵךְ and בֹּא־יָבֹא in v.6—do these emphasize certainty, duration, or processual journey?
Is there wordplay between זֶרַע (seed) and זֶרַע (offspring/descendants) in vv.5-6, connecting agricultural metaphor to restoration of Israel's posterity?
How does the progression from plural 'they who sow' (v.5) to singular 'he' (v.6) function—universalization, individuation, or both?
Does the agricultural journey in v.6 (going out/coming back) metaphorically encode pilgrimage to Jerusalem in the Songs of Ascents collection?
Why does רִנָּה (joyful singing) appear in vv.2, 5, and 6—is this accidental or deliberate sonic/thematic thread connecting sections?
